I see.  Thanks.

I am afraid JUnit won't do that for you.  However, I am pretty sure that you can do it through java.lang.Runtime yourself.  You'll need two
classes.  The first class create one run time instance for each test and passing the name of the test as parameter, the second class can have a
main method that will call different test method depending on the different parameters passed in.

In this way, you have a main process that spawns different testing processes.

Hope this helps.

> I'm trying to test an entire application. Each test will start the
> application, login, and test a specific piece of functionality. At the start
> of each test I call the application's main() method, and at the end I call
> it's shutdown() method. The application was not designed such that main() can
> be called multiple times. Doing so leads to duplicate daemon threads, and
> painfull initialization problems. Also, each test needs to start with an
> initialized data base.
